bibl.note: This is a letter from John W. Mills to Joseph D. Hamilton, dated August 2, 1847. Mills apologizes for misplacing a letter to Hamilton that contained some money. He also mentions the upcoming election and that he hopes the Whigs will beat the Democrats.

div1.p: By some incalcuble mischance the letter I wrote you soon after my marriage enclosing the money for the ring, was instead of being mailed, mislaid, and was to my very great mortification, found safely put away not very long since — I hope, Joe, that you will allow me to make the "Amends honorable" for I am truly ashamed that you have been treated so shablily — I trust then that you will understand that it was any thing but an intentional oversight —

We have nothing new here. Our Election is now going on, and very little excitement. The Democrats are sanguine about their success, but I think we will be too strong for them, notwithstanding the apathy among the whigs —
Please present me very kindly to your Mother & sister, and to other friends —
I am writing in a great hurry, and must ask you to excuse my very hasty letter — Accept sir my assurances of regard and believe me
